DOC.HEAD: U.S. and Panamanian Soldiers Have Had Several Confrontations
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Several incidents between U.S. and Panamanian troops have occurred this year before the U.S. invasion. Here is a list of major ones:

Jan. 6 _ Nine launches and two helicopters from the U.S. Southern Command went to the southern outlet of the Panama Canal. The Southern Command said it was a training mission; the Panamanian Defense Forces called it intimidation. March 1 _ One Panamanian was killed and two were wounded when they stepped on unexploded munitions in a military zone, the Southern Command said. March 3 _ Panamanian soldiers held nine Southern Command school buses carrying 100 children for three hours on grounds the buses did not have proper license plates. Aug. 8 _ U.S. forces detained 20 Panamanians, including nine soldiers who had tried to block maneuvers on U.S.-controlled territory, the Southern Command reported. They were were released a few hours later. Aug. 9 _ Southern Command tanks blocked the entrance to Fort Amador and helicopters flew over the area at the southern end of the canal. The Southern Command said it acted because Panama detained two U.S. soldiers. The Americans were exchanged for two Panamanians detained by the Americans that day. Aug. 17 _ The Southern Command conducted maneuvers at 11 installations along the Panama Canal. U.S. officials said they were enforcing their rights under the Panama Canal treaties; Panama said the United States was violating the treaties. Oct. 3 _ Panamanian soldiers attempted a coup against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. American soldiers blocked some routes to Defense Forces headquarters, but not all, and Noriega loyalists rescued him. Oct. 31 _ U.S. forces blocked highways and held maneuvers along the canal with tanks and aircraft. Panama called it an attempt at intimidation. Nov. 20-21 _ The Southern Command blocked access to Health Ministry installations with tanks, accusing Panamanian forces of doing the same to Gorgas Hospital, a U.S. installation. All forces withdraw two days later. Dec. 16 _ Panamanian soldiers fatally wounded an American officer. The United States said the officer and his companions were unarmed; the Panamanians said the Americans provoked the confrontation. Dec. 18 _ An Army officer shot and wounded a Panamanian police corporal. Dec. 20 _ President Bush ordered U.S. troops into combat in Panama City on a mission to seize Noriega to face federal drug charges in the United States.
